Detailed Description

The PCIe_IF class provides the actual basic read/write access to hardware registers. This class implements the only the common methods used by all PCIe driver interfaces. More advanced driver interfaces add functionality based on what they can expect the Windows kernel mode driver to support. This class gauruntees that the following methods are available:
  • read8/16/32()
  • write8/16/32()
  • block read versions of the above
  • getPCIConfigRegs()
  • getPCIDriverInfo()
  • getPCIResourcesStr()
  • getDriverVersionStr()
  • getDriverResourcesStr()
  • getPCICapabiltiesStr()

This class extends the base class to provide the exact methods to access the hardware registers in a LSC FPGA on PCIEpress card. The hardware (FPGA) is accessed using specific DeviceIoControl() calls to the corresponding Windows kernel-mode device driver.

A PCI Express device is accessed through the PCI bus address space mapped into a processor's memory map, so it is basically a PCI device as far as the software is concerned. A PCI device can have 6 windows of addresses into its onboard memory. These are known as BARs. Each BAR can start at an arbitrary address in the processor's map. Therefore to read/write to registers in different BARs of the device, the correct base address needs to be specified. Since the base address is completely arbitrary (setup by the OS at boot), the software will pass the BAR it wants to access in the upper nibble of the addr parameter to the read/write methods. The access layer driver code will then pass that BAR to the device driver code so it can generate the proper CPU bus address to reach the BAR of the device on the PCI bus. Addressing convention used throughout: 32 bit addr = [BAR(31:28)][Address(27:0)]

The specific driver and board to open are identified by:

  • GUID = Driver ID = the specific Windows driver to open such as lscpcie2.sys or lscdma.sys
  • Vendor/Device = Board ID = specify the specific board to attach to. Each type of Lattice eval board will have a unique PCI Device ID.
  • SubSystem = Demo ID = specify which IP to connect to. Each demo IP design has a specific ID stored in the PCI SubSystem Vendor/Device registers.
  • Instance = which occurrence of the board/demo to attach to if multiple, identical boards are in the system.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

PCIe_IF::PCIe_IF (  const GUID *  pGUID,
const char *  pBoardID,
const char *  pDemoID,
uint32_t  devNum = 1,
const char *  pFriendlyName = NULL,
const char *  pFunctionName = NULL
) 
 

Create an interface to a Lattice PCIe Driver and eval board. This requires opening the Win32 device driver that provides access to the card that the FPGA is located on. The driver needs to have been installed on the PC using the "Add New Hardware" wizard.

Parameters:
pGUID specify the driver to open (see GUID list)
pBoardID the PCI Vendor and Device register pair indicating the board to open
pDemoID the PCI SubSystem regsiter value indicating the Demo IP to open
devNum the instance of the board (i.e. locate and open the 2nd SC80 x4 board)
pFriendlyName (NOT USED) text string naming the board, set in registry,
pFunctionName text string naming a specific driver function to open (i.e. use DMA chan #1)
Note:
If run-time VERBOSE is set then display information during opening driver and board.
Exceptions:
PCIe_IF_Error if the specified Driver/Board/Demo/Instance can not be found

Returns:

Definition at line 482 of file PCIe_IF.cpp.

References PCIResourceInfo_t::BAR, getPCIDriverInfo(), PCIResourceInfo_t::hasInterrupt, PCIResourceInfo_t::intrVector, PCI_BAR_t::memMapped, PCI_BAR_t::nBAR, PCIResourceInfo_t::numBARs, PCI_BAR_t::physStartAddr, and PCI_BAR_t::size.

bool PCIe_IF::getDriverVersionStr (  string &  outs  ) 
 

Return the string containing the driver version and build date. The drivers implement an IOCTL that returns the build number, date and description of the driver. This method gets that info from the kernel driver and returns it to the caller.

Returns:
true if info returned from driver or false if the driver doesn't implement the IOCTL code or something else failed.

Definition at line 459 of file PCIe_IF.cpp.

References DriverVerStr_t, and IOCTL_LSCPCIE_GET_VERSION_INFO.

bool PCIe_IF::getPCICapabiltiesStr (  string &  outs  ) 
 

Fill the string with info about the PCIe Capabilities structures. This information is read from the driver and the PCI config registers are parsed to see if a Capabilities list exists. If so, the list is wlaked and each discovered structure is parsed into readable format and saved into the return string.

Parameters:
outs the string to fill with the list data.
Returns:
true if successful; false if error

bool PCIe_IF::getPCIConfigRegs (  uint8_t *  pCfg  ) 
 

Return the 256 bytes of the device's PCI configuration space registers. These registers must be present on any PCI/PCIExpress device. They have a standard format.

Parameters:
pCfg user's location to store 256 bytes
Returns:
true if read byte OK, false if driver reports error

Return the device driver information structure. This includes the BAR assignments, interrupt info and the PCI cfg registers.

Parameters:
pInfo user's pointer that will point to the internal driver structure
Returns:
true (info obtained in constructor so always present)
Note:
Do not modify the contents of the structure! It is read only.

bool PCIe_IF::getPCIResourcesStr (  string &  outs  ) 
 

Return the PCI resources formatted into a displayable string. Caller supplies the C++ string object and this routine parses the standard PCI Cfg0 registers (0x00-0x3f) into human readable format. Mainly for diagnostic output.

Parameters:
outs caller supplied string to fill with formatted results
Returns:
true if CFG0 registers read and parsed, false if errors

int PCIe_IF::MmapDriver (  void   )  [protected]
 

Map the BAR address windows into a processes memory space using MMAP. The number of valid BARs is found from the initial creation. NOTE: This must be called after the PCI resource have been read from the driver and the PCIinfo structure is populated.

Referenced by PCIe_IF().

int PCIe_IF::OpenDriver (  HANDLE &  hnd,
const GUID *  pGUID,
const char *  pBoardID,
const char *  pDemoID,
uint32_t  instance = 1,
const char *  pFriendlyName = NULL,
const char *  pFunctionName = NULL
)  [protected]
 

Open a device driver via a device interface and return the Linux file handle. The device to open is specified using the /dev filename (pointed to by the GUID) The instance number of the device can also be specified, such as open the 2nd board of this type. If the driver supports opening various functions, such as DMA using a specific channel, then specify this function as a string in the pFunctionName parameter.

For Linux: GUID points to a string constant that holds the base device node in the /dev/ tree pBoardID points to the next part of the filename ("SC" or "ECP2M") pDemoID points to the next part of the filename ("Basic" or "SFIF") instance is a number 1, 2, etc. converted to a string to form the end of the filename pFunctionName is a string that is appended to the others to open some feature of the driver

/dev/lscpcie2/SC_Basic_1 /dev/lscpcie2/ECP2M_SFIF_2

The filename is created by concatenating GUID/pBoardID_pDemoID_instance/pFunctionName The file is then opened using this file name, and the returned handle will provide the interface to the driver.

the beauty of Linux and udev is that the /dev/ tree already contains all the enumerated Lattice PCIe boards (as detected by the driver upon installing or the PCI bus sub-system invoking the driver

Parameters:
hnd reference to caller supplied HANDLE to return open driver
pGUID pointer to the GUID identifying the Lattice PCIe device driver to open
pBoardID pointer a string identifying the PCI Vendor_Device pair in board's CFG0 space
pDemoID pointer a string identifying the SubSys register values used to identify a Demo
instance which instance of that board, if multiple in system
pFriendlyName string specifying the Window registery friendly name associated with device (NULL for now)
pFunctionName string specifying driver specific function to open (appended to the filename at open time)

bool PCIe_IF::read16 (  uint32_t  offset,
uint16_t *  val,
size_t  len,
bool  incAddr = true
)  [virtual]
 

Read a block of 16 bit registers from SC hardware via PCIe bus.

Parameters:
offset address of device registers to read from
val location of storage for data read
len number of 16 bit words to read (not byte count)
incAddr true if address increments for each operation, false to access the same address each time (FIFO access)
Returns:
true; false if address not multiple of 2
Note:
error in reading will cause hardware exception

Implements LatticeSemi_PCIe::RegisterAccess.

uint32_t PCIe_IF::read32 (  uint32_t  offset  )  [virtual]
 

Read 32 bits from an SC hardware register via PCIe bus. This is done with 2 16 bit reads because the SC900 only has a 16 bit wide data bus and will not allow accesses larger than 16 bits.

Parameters:
offset address of device register to read from
val location of storage for data read
Returns:
true; false if address not multiple of 4
Note:
error in reading will cause hardware exception

Implements LatticeSemi_PCIe::RegisterAccess.
